text: I feel intense fear or anxiety about social situations where I might be judged or evaluated.
I avoid social situations because I'm afraid of embarrassing myself or being humiliated.
I worry excessively about what others think of me before, during, and after social interactions.
I experience physical symptoms like sweating, trembling, or blushing in social situations.
I feel like people are watching and judging me even when they're not paying attention to me.
I avoid speaking up in groups or meetings because I'm afraid of saying something wrong.
I feel anxious about eating, drinking, or writing in front of others.
I replay social interactions in my mind, analyzing what I said and how others might have perceived me.
I feel like my mind creates an imaginary audience that's constantly judging me.
I experience intense fear before social events and often cancel plans at the last minute.
I feel comfortable and confident in social situations.
I can speak up in groups without worrying about being judged.
I don't worry about what others think of me in social situations.
I can easily engage in conversations with new people without feeling anxious.
I feel relaxed and at ease when I'm the center of attention.
I avoid eye contact or speaking to people because I'm afraid they'll see my anxiety.
I feel like people can see how nervous or anxious I am, which makes me even more anxious.
I worry that I'll do or say something that will cause others to think negatively of me.
I feel like my social anxiety prevents me from living the life I want to live.
I can handle criticism or negative feedback in social situations without it affecting me deeply.
